intro_at_sea.title: Voyage to Stormwreck Isle
intro_at_sea.read_aloud:
Your journey has been smooth sailing so far. You left the bustling port of Neverwinter a few days ago, heading for an island with the foreboding name of Stormwreck Isle. But you woke this morning to a blood-red sunrise, and dark clouds overhead threaten a violent storm.

As lightning flashes across the sky, a monster hauls itself up onto the deck!

“These waters belong to the Scaled Queen. I’m here to collect her tribute.”
intro_at_sea.gm_guidance:
This is the opening scene and tutorial framing. Briefly introduce yourself as DM and explain that you describe the world and roll for monsters, while players describe what their heroes do.
Show the ship illustration, then the merrow illustration as it appears. Use an intimidating voice for the merrow’s line.
Make clear to the players that they are free to choose how to respond: fight, negotiate, trick, or other creative ideas. Emphasize that D&D uses a d20 plus modifiers from their sheet to resolve uncertain actions.
Do not start combat yet; this is a flexible encounter that can go social, shenanigans, or combat depending on player choices.
Transition to the next node as soon as players start declaring concrete approaches to dealing with the merrow.

merrow_negotiation_scene.title: Negotiating with the Merrow
merrow_negotiation_scene.read_aloud:
The merrow looms over you on the slick deck, water streaming from its scaled form. Its lip curls in a cruel grin as it eyes the ship’s cargo.

“These waters belong to the Scaled Queen,” it growls. “Her tribute is four hundred gold pieces… or everything in your hold.”
merrow_negotiation_scene.gm_guidance:
This node handles structured negotiation over tribute. The merrow’s initial demand is 400 gp or the equivalent value in goods, representing the value of all the goods in the hold.
Allow the characters to offer coin, cargo, promises, or other bargains. For each concrete attempt to haggle, threaten, or deceive, call for a Charisma check using the most appropriate skill: Persuasion to bargain, Intimidation to cow it, Deception to lie about the value or ownership of the cargo.
Each successful DC 15 Charisma (Persuasion/Intimidation/Deception) check reduces the demanded tribute by 100 gp. Track the current demanded amount; once it reaches 0 gp or the players agree to pay the current amount, the merrow is satisfied and leaves.
If the players ask about the Scaled Queen here, the merrow explains that she is a huge, two-headed merrow who carries the special blessing of Demogorgon, the Prince of Demons. Use this to foreshadow future threats.
If the players stall, refuse to pay anything, or repeatedly fail checks while being defiant, the merrow’s patience runs out and it attacks, transitioning to combat. If they pay at least half (200 gp) and have been somewhat respectful or fearful, the merrow may depart with a final threat instead of fighting.
Encourage creative bargaining: offering future favors, misleading about the cargo, or trying to convince the merrow that the Scaled Queen would prefer them alive. Translate these into checks with advantage or disadvantage as appropriate.
If the players come up with a plan that clearly outwits or embarrasses the merrow (e.g., tricking it into taking worthless goods), you can let it leave in a huff without combat, possibly vowing revenge.

merrow_shenanigans_scene.title: Shenanigans on the Stormy Deck
merrow_shenanigans_scene.read_aloud: The storm-tossed deck bucks beneath your feet as rain lashes down. Barrels roll and ropes swing wildly while the merrow snarls at you, water streaming from its scaled hide. There’s chaos all around—plenty to turn to your advantage, if you’re clever.
merrow_shenanigans_scene.gm_guidance:
This node focuses on creative, nonstandard tactics. Encourage players to describe any wild idea they have and respond with, “You can try!”
Examples from the text:
• Rolling a barrel to push the merrow overboard: call for a Strength (Athletics) check, likely DC 13–15 depending on setup and distance.
• Dropping a sail or rigging on it to blind or restrain it: call for a Dexterity check or relevant tool/attack roll, DC around 13–15.
• Persuading the crew to rush it: call for a Charisma (Intimidation or Persuasion) check, DC 13–15; on success, the crew provides advantage on a subsequent check or imposes disadvantage on the merrow’s actions.
If a character has a specific spell or class ability that fits (e.g., a spell to restrain, shove, or frighten), help the player use that ability instead of a generic ability check.
On success, a shenanigan might:
• Knock the merrow overboard, ending the encounter without full combat.
• Impose a strong condition (prone, restrained, blinded) that gives the party a big edge if combat starts.
• Convince the merrow that the ship is too dangerous a target, causing it to retreat.
On failure, the attempt might miss, partially work, or backfire, angering the merrow and making combat more likely. Use failures to escalate tension rather than instantly punish; only move to combat when it feels natural.
If the players keep using shenanigans and succeed multiple times, you can resolve the encounter entirely here by having the merrow retreat or be forced back into the sea.
If at any point a player declares a direct attack, or the merrow retaliates violently, transition to the combat node.

merrow_combat_scene.title: Combat with the Merrow Extortionist
merrow_combat_scene.read_aloud: With a roar, the merrow lunges forward, claws and jagged teeth bared as lightning flashes overhead. The slick deck rocks beneath your feet as battle erupts on the storm-tossed ship.
merrow_combat_scene.gm_guidance:
This node represents structured combat with the merrow. Initiative is rolled now or has just been rolled. The merrow looks fearsome but is intentionally not too dangerous; the characters should be able to defeat it in 1–2 rounds.
Use the provided stat block:
• Large Monstrosity, typically chaotic evil
• AC 13 (natural armor), HP 30 (4d10 + 8)
• Speed 10 ft., swim 40 ft.
• STR 16 (+3), DEX 10 (+0), CON 15 (+2), INT 8 (−1), WIS 10 (+0), CHA 9 (−1)
• Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 10
• Languages Abyssal, Aquan, Common
• Challenge 1 (100 XP), Proficiency Bonus +2
• Amphibious: can breathe air and water.
Actions:
• Multiattack: two Rend attacks.
• Rend: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (2d4 + 3) piercing damage.
On each player’s turn, walk them through their options: weapon attacks, spell attacks, cantrips, and class features. Help new players read their character sheets and choose actions.
On the merrow’s turn, it closes to melee and uses Multiattack with Rend against the nearest or most threatening character. It fights aggressively but not suicidally; if reduced to low hit points and clearly outmatched, it might attempt to dive overboard to escape, which you can treat as a narrative defeat.
Keep the fight fast-paced and cinematic. Emphasize the storm, the rocking deck, and the danger of being near the rail, but don’t overcomplicate with extra hazards unless players specifically interact with them.
When the merrow is defeated (reduced to 0 hit points or forced to flee), move to the wrap-up node.

post_merrow_wrapup.title: After the Merrow Encounter
post_merrow_wrapup.read_aloud:
With a splash, the merrow disappears into the ocean deeps and the ship continues on its way. The sailors raise a cheer, and the storm brewing overhead seems not quite so threatening now.

And that brings you to the end of your first taste of adventure.
post_merrow_wrapup.gm_guidance:
Use this scene to close out the merrow tutorial encounter and pivot toward the main adventure at Dragon’s Rest.
If the merrow was killed, its body might sink beneath the waves or be washed overboard; if it fled, describe it vanishing into the dark water. In either case, the immediate danger is gone and the storm begins to ease.
Let players briefly reflect on what happened, check for any immediate looting or questions, then move the narrative forward to the approach to Stormwreck Isle.
This is a good moment to reassure new players, answer rules questions, and set expectations that the story continues on the island.

arrival_at_dragons_rest.title: Arrival at Dragon’s Rest
arrival_at_dragons_rest.read_aloud:
Stormwreck Isle—now visible off the bow—promises rare wonders. Seaweed shimmers in countless brilliant colors below you, and rays of sunlight defy the overcast sky to illuminate the lush grass and dark basalt rock of the island. Avoiding the rocks jutting up from the ocean, your ship makes its way toward a calm harbor on the island’s north side.

A large, open-air temple comes into view, perched on the edge of a cliff high above you. The ship drops anchor at the mouth of the harbor, and two sailors row you ashore. You have plenty of time to admire the towering statue at the center of the temple, depicting a wizened man surrounded by seven songbirds. A long path winds up the side of the cliff to the temple, dotted along the way with doorways cut into the rock.

The sailors set you ashore on a rickety dock, where a large rowboat is neatly tied. They point to the base of the path and wish you good luck before they row back to the ship. Your visit to Dragon’s Rest begins!
arrival_at_dragons_rest.gm_guidance:
This scene introduces Stormwreck Isle and the cloister of Dragon’s Rest. Emphasize the contrast between the earlier storm and the calmer, almost mystical atmosphere of the island.
Mention that each character has a specific reason for coming to the cloister (from their character sheets), or invite players to invent their own reasons for seeking Elder Runara’s wisdom and assistance.
Encourage players to introduce their characters to each other if they haven’t already: names, appearances, and (optionally) their reasons for visiting Dragon’s Rest. Some may keep their motives secret.
Ask for the party’s marching order as they begin up the path: who is in front, who is in the middle, and who brings up the rear. Make a note of this marching order; it will matter for upcoming encounters on the path.
There is no immediate danger here; this is a social and descriptive scene setting up the approach to the cloister and the first island encounter (“Drowned Sailors”).

drowned_sailors_approach.title: Drowned Sailors Emerge
drowned_sailors_approach.read_aloud: As you’re about to leave the beach and start your climb, you hear a ruckus of splashing and a wet, gurgling moan behind you. Three figures are shambling up from the water’s edge, about thirty feet away. They’re dressed as sailors, but their skin is gray and they look drowned. Sea water drools from their slack mouths as they lurch toward you.
drowned_sailors_approach.gm_guidance:
This is the setup for the first on-island combat encounter. Three zombies—animated corpses of sailors from a recent shipwreck—shamble toward the party from the water’s edge, about 30 feet away.
Make it clear that the characters have a choice: they can turn and fight the zombies, or they can continue up the path and leave the slow, shambling zombies behind. The zombies will not pursue up the path if the party chooses to flee.
If the players choose to fight, transition to the combat node and follow standard initiative rules. If they choose to avoid the zombies, narrate their escape and move on toward Dragon’s Rest.
If players ask what their characters know about zombies, call for DC 10 Intelligence checks. On a success, they recall that zombies are hard to kill and that a particularly powerful blow (a critical hit) or radiant damage can help finish them off, bypassing their Undead Fortitude. Use this as a hint but don’t overwhelm new players with rules jargon.
Keep the tone eerie but not overwhelming; this is an early-level encounter meant to teach basic combat and tactical choices, including the option to avoid a fight.

drowned_sailors_combat.title: Combat with the Drowned Sailors
drowned_sailors_combat.read_aloud: The drowned sailors lurch closer, gray hands outstretched, seawater pouring from their mouths and clothes. Their dead eyes fix on you as they stagger up the sand, ready to slam into you with unnatural strength.
drowned_sailors_combat.gm_guidance:
This is the first full combat encounter on Stormwreck Isle. Use it to teach initiative, turns, and basic tactics.
Set up:
• Three zombies (drowned sailors) start about 30 feet from the party on the beach.
• Roll initiative for all characters and zombies; track order on your notes.
On the zombies’ turns:
• They move toward the nearest characters and make melee attacks if in range.
Use the provided zombie stat block:
• Medium Undead, typically neutral evil
• AC 8, HP 22 (3d8 + 9)
• Speed 20 ft.
• STR 13 (+1), DEX 6 (−2), CON 16 (+3), INT 3 (−4), WIS 6 (−2), CHA 5 (−3)
• Saving Throws Wis +0
• Damage Immunities poison; Condition Immunities poisoned
• Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 8
• Languages: understands languages it knew in life but can’t speak
• Challenge 1/4 (50 XP), Proficiency Bonus +2
Traits:
• Undead Fortitude: If damage reduces the zombie to 0 hit points, it makes a Constitution saving throw with DC 5 + damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, it drops to 1 hit point instead of dying.
• Unusual Nature: The zombie doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep.
Actions:
• Slam: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) bludgeoning damage.
Teaching tips:
• On each character’s turn, walk them through their available actions (attack, cast a spell, move, etc.).
• When Undead Fortitude keeps a zombie from dying, describe it narratively: “That should have finished it off, but it refuses to stop moving!”
• When a zombie takes radiant damage (such as from sacred flame), describe it howling in agony to hint that radiant damage is especially effective.
• If players ask what their characters know, allow DC 10 Intelligence checks as in the previous node.
The zombies fight until all three are defeated or the party flees up the path. If the characters decide to run mid-fight, they can still escape; the zombies don’t pursue up the path.
Runara’s Aid: If the zombies defeat the adventurers (all characters drop to 0 hit points), Elder Runara arrives and rescues them. Narrate the characters blacking out and later waking in a temple in Dragon’s Rest. Runara explains she heard the sounds of combat and arrived just in time to prevent the zombies from dragging them into the sea. Treat this as a narrative failure but do not end the adventure.

post_drowned_sailors_resolution.title: After the Drowned Sailors
post_drowned_sailors_resolution.read_aloud: Leaving the drowned sailors behind—whether as shattered corpses on the sand or shambling figures fading into the mist—you turn your attention back to the path that winds up toward the cliffside temple of Dragon’s Rest.
post_drowned_sailors_resolution.gm_guidance:
This node wraps up the drowned sailors encounter and moves the party toward Dragon’s Rest proper.
If the party defeated the zombies, describe the remains on the beach and any brief reactions the characters might have. If they fled, describe the zombies quickly falling behind, unable to climb the path. If they were defeated and rescued, describe them awakening in a temple chamber in Dragon’s Rest with Elder Runara explaining she heard the fight and intervened.
Regardless of outcome, the adventure continues at Dragon’s Rest, where the characters will learn more about the island’s dangers and meet Elder Runara.
Use this moment to adjust tone from immediate danger back to exploration and roleplay. You can foreshadow that there are more undead or shipwreck-related threats on the island.
From here, transition into the broader Dragon’s Rest storyline as outlined in the full adventure.

stormwreck_isle_destination.title: Onward into Dragon’s Rest
stormwreck_isle_destination.read_aloud: You leave the beach behind and follow the winding path toward the open-air temple of Dragon’s Rest. Above, the towering statue of a wizened man surrounded by seven songbirds watches over the harbor. Whatever trials Stormwreck Isle holds, your journey has truly begun.
stormwreck_isle_destination.gm_guidance:
Use this destination node as an epilogue for the provided text and a handoff into the rest of the Stormwreck Isle adventure.
Summarize briefly: the characters survived a storm at sea, faced down a merrow extortionist, arrived at Stormwreck Isle, and confronted drowned sailors on the beach. These experiences have given them a taste of combat, negotiation, and creative problem-solving.
From here, the campaign continues with the full Dragon’s Rest storyline: meeting Elder Runara, exploring the cloister, and uncovering the deeper dangers threatening Stormwreck Isle.
This node should have no outgoing edges; it marks the conclusion of this excerpt and the transition to the next chapter of play, which will be handled by subsequent content.
